content.description:
A "gimme" 5.5, it's a good way to get up on top of the pillar to set up the other routes on it.  Sling tree limbs for anchor. 

  The pillar has 3 (three!) bolts WITHOUT rappel rings on top, and the bolts are well back from the edge.  The top of the pillar is a 3' jump across a 40-50' drop, to get to the main rock to the left.  You may end up rappelling from the tree, or counterweight rappelling.  Thanks for the bolts, guys!  -JSH
content.protection: G-PG gear, some of it quite fiddly.  Bring cams up to #2, and some hexes for the flake.  The tree, of course, is off.
content.location: Start next to large boulder at base of tree on left side of pillar; go straight up small dihedral and trend left towards top to avoid the tree.

content.description: A balancy/reachy crux about 20 feet up. Relatively easy up to that point.
content.protection: Looked scarce for leading, though we didn't pay much attention on top-rope. Gear anchor up top (there is a crack and a tree).
content.location: This climb is on the face to the right of cool hand luke and can be climbed on the same anchor without a threat of a huge swing.

content.description: Like the real Sacs Fifth Avenue, this one doesn't come cheap.  I've only seen one person actually complete this one; he confirmed the grade in the guidebook at 5.11a/b.  There are, apparently, two different ways to do it; neither one is easier.  It's a nice gauge in that each move is progressively harder; you can judge your progress by how high you get.
content.protection: There is absolutely no protection whatsoever on this route.  Top rope only.  Bolted TR anchor.
content.location: Climb the blank, arching face to the right of Arete I.  Stay off both aretes - climb the face only.  5.1 scramble to easier walk-off terrain, from the top.

content.description: Excellent, tricky route.  The crux for most is simply getting off the ground.  Might want to pad the sharp rocks with a pack...
content.protection: PG13-R pro - what gear there is, is sparse and small.  It's possible to build an anchor using only static line, but it requires some ingenuity - and a lot of static line.
content.location: Climb the right-most arete on the section of wall from which the detached pillar came away. 4th-class scramble to reach easier walk-off.

content.description: A surprisingly difficult route for its grade, this route - just like a true hustler - lends a false sense of security, then leaves you in the lurch.
content.protection: Barely adequate enough to achieve PG status.  It's possible to build an anchor using only static line, but it requires some ingenuity - and a lot of static line.  Gear anchor otherwise.
content.location: Start in dihedral/chimney approx. 15 feet right of Cool Hand Luke; work your way onto the right face, and follow crack to top.  5.1 scramble up to easier walk-off terrain from top.

content.description: Never climbed this one; including it for completeness sake.
content.protection: Sparse to non-existant.  Bolted TR anchor.
content.location: This route is on the backside of the Scrotum Pole, opposite Easy Rider and Up A Tree and to the right of Can He Share?  Climb the face of the detached pillar to the right of Can He Share?.  5.1 scramble to easier walk-off terrain, from the top.

content.description:
Thin, facey route with both a low and high crux, this route is again suprisingly difficult for its grade.  Anyone leading this should be aware that it's VERY spicy, and there is groundfall potential throughout nearly the entire route.  All of the gear is small, and hard to find. 

  The pillar has 3 (three!) bolts WITHOUT rappel rings on top, and the bolts are well back from the edge.  The top of the pillar is a 3' jump across a 40-50' drop, to get to the main rock to the left.  You may end up rappelling from the tree, or counterweight rappelling.  Thanks for the bolts, guys!  -JSH
content.protection: Thin, sparse, hidden gear.  Bolted TR anchor.
content.location: Climb the face 5 feet right of Up A Tree, staying off the arete to the right.

content.description: Climb obvious offwidth and face above.  Two cruxes - first ten feet, and half-way up the face (long reach on iffy holds).
content.protection: PG pro.  Tricky to place.  Gear anchor at top.
content.location: Left of the detached pillar is a flat wall with an obvious offwidth crack at the bottom, a blank face above, and a corner system above that.  Climb the obvious offwidth, through the face, and up through the corner system.  4th-class scramble up to top of cliff, or careful 3rd-class traverse on ledge (right) to easier walk-off.

content.description: Start in the center of the face on the Drive In wall. Avoid the easier holds of the climbs on either side.
content.protection: Trad, Natural Pro for Tope Rope.
content.location: The Drive In amphitheater is next area you come to, walking past the Terror Dome.It hosts a variety of moderate, fun climbs that stay shaded most of the day.

content.description: This route is, like so many others in this area, deceptively difficult.  Very balancy, with slopers for key holds, there are two cruxes.  Be warned that a fall will likely result in a pendulum if the anchor isn't set properly.
content.protection: No protection.  Bolted TR anchors, or pad and sling a large tree with the bolts as a back-up.
content.location: Climb the arete to the right of Sac's Fifth Avenue.  5.1 scramble to easier walk-off terrain, from the top.

content.description: This seldom-done route climbs a rounded arete approximately 8 feet left of Cool Hand Luke.  I've never climbed it; including it for completeness sake.
content.protection: Unknown, but from the ground it doesn't look very good.  Gear-only anchor.
content.location: Start approximately 8 feet left of Cool Hand Luke; climb face and rounded arete to top.  Easy walk-off.

content.description: This route might, at first, seem soft; perhaps no harder than mild 5.7.  However, once you get towards the top - and start on the slightly overhanging, slanted part of the arete - you'll see why it's actually fairly graded.  If you duck off onto the easier face to the left at the top, you're only gypping yourself.
content.protection:
Spicy lead, especially at the top (very sparse).  Recommend TRing this one.   

  The pillar has 3 (three!) bolts WITHOUT rappel rings on top, and the bolts are well back from the edge.  The top of the pillar is a 3' jump across a 40-50' drop, to get to the main rock to the left.  You may end up rappelling from the tree, or counterweight rappelling.  Thanks for the bolts, guys!  -JSH
content.location: Climb the arete approximately 3 feet right of Easy Rider and 10 feet right of Up A Tree.  5.1 scramble to easier walk-off terrain, from the top.

content.description: Remarkably well-shaded yet open belay area; it's a great spot for summer climbing.  Another favorite spot for guides/groups, this area has a good range of climbing from 5.4 to some of the hardest and tallest routes in PK.
